TERRITORIAL NEWS.

EDMONTON.

From the Bulletin, March 12th.

G. A. Blake, of Belmont, shot a large white swan or American goose near his place last week. This bird is a native of the far north and is seldom seen here.

The assessment of the Edmonton school district for the year ending June 30th, amounts to $896,568, $223,873 being personal property.

The annual meeting of the Edmonton Bible Association was held at Mr. McTaggart's shop on Tuesday evening. The secretary read a communication from Col. Macpherson, stating that the deputation had received no answer to their petition concerning the sale of the association. It had been decided that an order for the necessary amount be sent to the association, and the money stored here on receipt, by the department of the price fixed. Also that the officers of the association be elected as would be allowed. Messrs. Stott and J. A. Macdonald were appointed auditors, and the meeting adjourned until next month, when they will meet as at the same place.

Dr. McKay, H. B. chief trader of the Slave Lake district, arrived from Slave Lake on Friday. He experienced a heavy snowstorm at the Athabasca Landing, but was enabled to proceed and met success at Slave Lake and horses are wintering out well. The moose and caribou country is reported to be in good shape, and there is plenty of game.

A school meeting was held in Saskatoon district, on Monday last, at the call of the inspector of Catholic schools, Rev. Père Leduc. Considerable interest was manifested in the proceedings of the management of the district. He called upon the trustees to produce bonds for the school, which they refused to do. After somewhat animated discussion the meeting was closed and the inspectors returned to Edmonton. The Board of Education at Regina, he received an answer by telegraph that as soon as his complaints in writing were received a new election of trustees would be ordered.

The concert at Port Saskatchewan in aid of the school fund, which was attended, there being considerable delegations from Edmonton and Clover Bar in attendance. A short review of the programme was given in the schoolhouse, and refreshments were afterwards served in the Palace Hotel near by. The proceeds from one and above all places amounted to some $600.

BATTLEFIELD.

From the Herald of March 19th.

A brigade of carts—pulled for the railway on the 19th.

Messrs. H. F. Montgomery and Wm. Ferrier have been invited to pay a visit to their friends.

At a meeting of the Protestant School Trustees, held last evening Mrs. A. Macdonald, of this place, presented a cheque to fill the vacancy caused by Miss Buchanan declining to come here.

The contract for supplying limestone to the railway company for the purpose of making lime for the railway line between Battle-field and Clark's Crossing has been awarded to Mr. Topper, of Vancouver, and for the work between Clark's Crossing and Humboldt to Baptist Boyer.

A train of freight, and on its movement continued by Mr. Fraser, came from Swift Current on Tuesday. Several hordes belonging to local merchants are about to leave. Freighters generally are getting ready to take the road as soon as there is a thaw.

FORT MACLEOD.

From the Gazette of March 22nd.

A gun club has been formed at Macleod. Guns ball shooting will be the leading amusement of the club.

A large get together was held on Wednesday night, seventeen carts on the road. About seven miles of the road was covered.

Rev. R. Hilton held service at Pincher Creek on Sunday. Mr. Bourne took his place at Macleod. Rev. Mr. Van Tienhoven held service at the Roman Catholic church, and Rev. J. McLennan at the Methodist church.

Arrangements have been made to build a Methodist church at Pincher Creek this summer. A building committee has been formed and the site selected, and it is expected that the building will be completed by September.

A small flock of geese passed north over Macleod on Monday afternoon. So far we have heard nothing of the geese this season. These geese had not ordinarily been seen, for they were running their normal right into a snow storm.

Macleod Creek is at length to have a postoffice.

MEDICINE HAT.

From the Times of March 20th.

The thermometer was only 65 degrees above zero last Sunday.

For the necessaries amongst us who have been away from home, two cricket clubs and several fast houses, we ought to put in a pretty lively summer amongst the Indians of this quarter.

Capt. Norrie, for the past eighteen months in charge of the Mounted Police here, is about to be transferred to British Columbia.

It was on the 14th inst., that the ice broke up in the Saskatchewan river. What could the people have thought? That the first bit of ice was clear of the river this early season? However, they may consider themselves lucky if the six feet that remained on the river is all that should proceed in carrying out our plans once more.

Last Tuesday Geo. Macdonald, while driving his team of oxen across the Deer ranch, came very near calling for a check for the other shore. At this season, however, the river is generally frozen over for a very large part of the year.

The Seven Persons River is inevitably high, though the river is not so high as usual. But George had no fear of what might happen to him.

On the 19th inst., Mr. Steele, an eastern territorial steel of sheep, by his method forth into the raging river, was swept away by the current.

"Prepared," says Hugh Dempsey, would say, may the capillary apparatus of the human system stand the pressure. The question of the sheep's capability could only be told in Mr. Macdonald's graphic style, and he yet fails to tell the story. The death of Steele was tragic in the extreme, and it is with a sense of pleasure that we hear that the sheep has been found on the North American continent that George and his steel, though separated by the water, have again met on this side of the Seven Persons.

GENERAL NEWS.

Ex-Ald. Hartop, of Guelph, Ont., has abandoned the United States. His habitation is in Canada.

Edward Turner, a young man who lived near Trenton, shot himself fatally with a shotgun yesterday. Dissipation seems to have been the cause.

David Alexander Herbert, of Wm. Blair, was run over and killed by a Grand Trunk train near Steveston, on the 26th ult.

The question of the establishment of a Legislative Council of New Brunswick has been thrown out by a vote of 12 to 6.

At noon on the 26th May, Stanley Steele, of Manchester, N. S., started for Montreal's Bank, and thinking Mr. Carriere would be there, went in and asked to see him privately. When they got into the office Steele drew a revolver and pointed it at Carriere, who made a flesh wound only, and a struggle ensued during which Carriere was shot dead. A moment later Steele fell to the ground. A minute after the first shot was fired, and four men overpowered Steele. His poverty impelled him to attempt to rob the bank. Carriere's wounds were not serious.

The Governor-General of Canada has approved the charter of the Canadian Rock Lake, South Valley and Brandon Railway Company, passed by the Manitoba legislature.

A bill in council has been passed, subjecting all patents issued by the Government for land and minerals to a clause rendering fishing rights.

Heck's boat house, Toronto, was burned on the 26th ult. Loss, $3,000. A large number of valuable private pictures were stored in the building.

A heavy gale on the 26th ult. blew down trees on the Island, Toronto, and damaged many buildings.

The directors of the various cemeteries, Toronto, have decided to close them against Sunday interments except in cases of extreme necessity.

The Court of Appeal, Montreal, has confirmed the judgment of the lower court, which declared legal the city by-law taxing a $250 annual ferry boat owned by the Longueuil Navigation Company. The appeal also concerned the judgment against the Canadian Shipping Company damages against the Toronto Mail for a libel contained in an article published 29th June, 1882.

In the arrival of the 350 Italian passengers of the steamer Beaver Scotia in the harbour late this morning and the 27th ult., the same that followed beggared description. They rushed into the Roman Catholic chapel seeking shelter for food like ravenous wolves. The force of the mass of people was so great that the officers who were present had to use their orders to keep the crowd back. The strong men crowded to the front with uplifted arms and their stern countenance seemed to say to the Italians, "Bread, bread!" It was impossible to regulate the distribution of food. The poor fellows were obliged to take milk and beer added to their portions.

Then A. Harding, the tileworks stage driver, came among the ill-fated, most of whom sat on the deck, and offered them refreshment. He was joined by Ferguson, a coach driver, on May 29th.

Pat Gunnan and Mat Turney, baymen, came on board and offered assistance, saying they had been on the scene of the disaster at the Kansas, which arrived on the 23rd ult., fourteen days from Liverpool. The harvesters were most anxious and well with weight. All the food the two young men were able to obtain was the particles of flour that had been thrown on the cleaner, and all the water they could get was that furnished by the "sweat" of the steamer. They are both in a very critical condition.

Jackson Marion, the murderer of John Cameron, was hanged at Beattie, Neb., on the 26th May, 1882. He was born in Oregon in April, 1872, nearly fifteen years ago, while driving to Grasshopper Falls, Kansas, to work on the St. Joe & Denver railroad grade.

STRAYED.

Strayed north from Humboldt, in November last a team of black ponies, one mare and two colts, aged three, four and five years old, brown, these animals lost across the prairie near the town of Humboldt. Also a Canadian mare, chestnut, with white star on forehead, aged three years old. Any person bringing the same to the owner will be handsomely rewarded.

HUMBOLDT, May 26th, 1882.

R. H. H. HUMBERTON, Stage Driver.

TOWN COUNCIL.

The Council met in the Council Chamber on Monday evening last.

Present—Couns. Stewart, Bain, and Couns. Bains, Stewart, and Redmond.

The minutes of the last meeting were read and adopted.

Minutes of the last meeting were read from Harold E. Fish for use of the room in Council building, from J. W. Ford for use of the A. C. Band, and from J. C. McMillan for reference to the cemetery.

SOMETHING.

Coun. Stewart made notice that he would introduce a by law to build and repair sidewalks, and also a by law to secure No. 1.

On motion of Coun. Stewart and Bains, four months rent were ordered to be paid.

Moved by Coun. Redmond, seconded by Coun. Bain, that the communication of W. E. Fish be referred to the Finance Committee.

COUNCIL.

Coun. Stewart gave notice that he would move, at the next meeting of the Council, that application be made to the Board of Works to have land laid out at the north side of the river for a public park for the town of Prince Albert.

Moved by Coun. Redmond, seconded by Coun. Bain, that the communication of W. E. Fish be referred to the Finance Committee.

COUNCIL.

Coun. Stewart gave notice that he would move, at the next meeting of the Council, that application be made to the Board of Works to have land laid out at the north side of the river for a public park for the town of Prince Albert.

Moved by Coun. Redmond, seconded by Coun. Bain, that the Court of Record be held on Monday, June 6th.

COUNCIL.

Moved by Coun. Bain, seconded by Coun. Redmond, that the collector be instructed to pay the amount of taxes assessed on the lands of Mr. Carter.

The by law for establishing the town was read a third time.

The Council adjourned to meet on Monday, 11th inst., at 7:30 p.m.

His Blessing.

"It doesn't everybody I'd trust my little gal," said the farmer, "but I'm glad to have this young stranger who had been charmed with Miss Sallie Skinner, and wished to carry her from the living card and into the grave."

This "little gal," who was five feet and eleven inches tall, has her feet fast (as she thought) to the ground, and her blushing face on the dear, dear old farmer's shoulder, and kept happy tears as he spoke.

"You must take good care of my birdling, Jack. Remember that she's been raised kind of tender-like. Two and a half years, and she's never been out an acre of corn a day till all that she is used to doing.

"Take her light work, such as making rail fences, and digging post holes, and burning brush, and so forth, but don't let her do too much work. She mustn't ask too much of her. It's hard work for old dad to give his little Skinner girl a birdling. He hasn't got two cents worth of birdling left in his taters now. Eat go, little, and be happy."

Ted Fish.

SUPREME COURT

TARIFF OF FEES.

Crown Prosecutions may, in addition to actual costs, be allowed, if incurred and paid, the following fees in civil actions cases (in addition to a summons)—

If defendant is a minor, $5.

If defendant is a corporation, $10.

In special cases the presiding judge may increase the latter fee to any sum not exceeding $20.

In other cases—

If undefended, $10.

If defendant, $25.

In criminal cases, the presiding judge may increase the fee to any sum not exceeding $50.

In any case of special difficulty and urgency, the Minister of Justice may allow such a fee as he deems an adequate compensation for the services rendered.

Summons may be allowed for the following—

In civil actions—

For summoning a party—each process, $1.

For executing processes executed and returned to the court (examiners of instruments) per day about $1.

Actual necessary disbursements in connection with serving and executing civil processes.

For superintending execution in capital cases, each execution, $10.

Actual and necessary disbursements and expenses connected with the levy of any execution, $1.

For executing any warrant, $2.

For levying money or other property by distress warrants. The same percentage of the amount realized shall be allowed as actual costs.

For salvage—

For salvage, the usual amount necessarily disbursed.

In other cases—

For every note necessarily traveled,

$1.

If in any case the latter fee does not cover actual and necessary expenditure, a judge may allow such a sum as will cover the expenditure.

Circles of the supreme Court:

In full for all services rendered for the Crown—

For each day's attendance, in person or by deputy, at a Court while actually engaged in the discharge of duty, $5.

Counsel may be allowed the following fees—

To appear by summons, jury, $10.

To appear by judge, $10.

Summoning a witness, each $10.

Examination, deposition, or examination of witness, each $10.

Taking every recognizance, $5.

Taking every recognizance to appear, each each way, $5.

Taking examination and making return, $5.

Every warrant for arrest if necessary.

For post mortem examination if actually necessary and actually made, $10.

Justice of the Peace—

For every warrant, a judge in criminal cases to be paid for each day actually engaged, $5.

Witnesses and Jurors—

Witnesses and jurors may, in criminal cases and appeals, be allowed the following fees—

For every day necessarily absent from their usual place of abode, making an affidavit, and returning to the Court, $5.

For every mile necessarily traveled by other means than railway, $1.

Witnesses may be allowed, in case paid, additional mileage when testifying and residing in addition to mileage as other witnesses, per day, $1.

Interpreters necessary, in capital cases only, to be paid, in addition to the same mileage as witnesses, and for each day actually engaged as interpreters, $5.

Witnesses may be allowed at the instance of a Judge, may in criminal cases be paid the following fees—

For first copy of evidence, per folio, $1.

For additional copies when required, $1.

If any preliminary investigation before magistrate or justice of the peace is held at the instance of the Crown, the same fees and charges may be allowed as for a hearing.

No tax or charge payable by the Crown shall be paid until certified as correct by a Judge, and by the Crown prosecutor if a Crown prosecutor is employed.
